reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central modeling assumption in the essay’s Section 3 (and, indirectly, the convergence framing in Section 2): that there will be identifiable agents/groups with sufficiently stable preferences to bargain/compromise. If that assumption failed comprehensively, the moral-trade route to mostly-great futures would be significantly weakened. However, the critique mostly asserts (via complexity/chaos metaphors) that fluid identities make trade/convergence impossible, without showing why bargaining couldn’t occur among whatever stable decision-making loci remain (institutions, AIs, coalitions, copies that coordinate, governance layers, etc.), or why preferences couldn’t be stable enough over relevant timescales. Several claims are overstated (e.g., “You cannot have trade or convergence”) and speculative. Still, it usefully flags a potentially under-discussed complication (posthuman identity/agent-boundary instability) that could reduce the applicability of the essay’s game-theoretic/bargaining intuitions.
title: Fluid post-human identities undermine stable agent negotiation models
